did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Afrika Bambaataa hip hop archive, circa 1972-2016.
did.physdesc: Vinyl records and other A/V Recordings, Financial Records, Manuscripts, Memorabilia, Photocopies, Photographs, Printed Materials, Publications.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Approximately 40,000 sound recordings representing Bambaataa's music collection from the 1970s to the present. The archive also includes books, documents, and files relating to the founding and spread of the Universal Zulu Nation; and videos, papers, and clothing.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Afrika Bambaataa is an American disc jockey, singer, and songwriter from the South Bronx, New York. Often called the “Godfather” of Hip Hop, Bambaataa has helped to define Hip Hop since it emerged in the South Bronx in the 1970s. One of a handful of Hip Hop's 1970s originators, Bambaataa gave Hip Hop its name, and was the first to define its core artistic elements - DJing, rapping, break dancing, and graffiti art - under one cultural umbrella. His cultural organization, the Universal Zulu Nation, has helped to spread Hip Hop culture throughout the world. His genre-defining 1982 song "Planet Rock" and subsequent electro-funk tracks have become icons of hip-hop and electronic music. In 2007 he was nominated for induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Approximately 40,000 sound recordings representing Bambaataa's music collection from the 1970s to the present. The archive also includes books, documents, and files relating to the founding and spread of the Universal Zulu Nation; and videos, papers, and clothing.

controlaccess.head: Places:
controlaccess.geogname: Bronx (New York, N.Y.) -- Social conditions -- 20th century.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Access to collection restricted until completion of processing, with the exception of vinyl records that have been individually cataloged.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use:
userestrict.p:
Vinyl that has been cataloged can be viewed but not played. Due to the fragility and potential degradation of moving image and sound recordings, viewing and listening is limited to items that have been digitized. If an item is in another media format, you may request to have the item digitized for access. Information on ordering access copies may be found on the Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections webpage.
Audio visual media that has been digitized: SR-6803, SR-6889, SR-8036, SR-8807, SR-8808, SR-8810 to SR-8816, SR-8818 to SR-8825, SR-10341 to SR-10370.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Afrika Bambaataa Hip Hop Archive, #8094. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

scopecontent.p: Series contains vinyl discs that are either not annotated or the annotations are small and were missed during the sorting of discs. While some effort was taken to bring together piences that were dense in copy-specific track preferences. These items are arranged in alphabetical order by artists’ last name or the name of the group. Each letter of the alphabet has a subseries. Compilations, soundtracks, and other albums with various artists are in subseries together. Artists and groups whose names start with a number are in a separate subseries. Most artists are alphabetized under the name they are most well-known as (e.g. Puff Daddy; Prince; Fela). The variations of names are contained in the Creator field. In a few cases, however, artists’ aliases were unknown, and they may have been listed under two different artist names.
